content.title: Carotid Endarterectomy Indications
content.definition: Evidence-based indications for carotid endarterectomy (CEA) based on symptom status and degree of stenosis, derived from landmark randomized controlled trials.

concepts.definition: CEA indicated for symptomatic patients with 50-99% stenosis who have experienced ipsilateral TIA or stroke within 6 months, based on NASCET and ECST trials.

clinical_features.timing: Within 14 days of symptom onset optimal
clinical_features.nnt: 6 to prevent one stroke at 5 years

concepts.definition: CEA may be considered for asymptomatic patients with 60-99% stenosis if perioperative risk <3%, based on ACAS and ACST trials.

clinical_features.nnt: 17 to prevent one stroke at 5 years

concepts.definition: Conditions that preclude or relatively contraindicate carotid endarterectomy.

clinical_features.evaluation: Duplex ultrasound, CTA or MRA for stenosis quantification
clinical_features.timing_benefit: Greatest benefit within 2 weeks of symptoms

diagnostic_criteria.NASCET_method: [(1 - Nd/Cc) × 100] where Nd = narrowest diameter, Cc = normal distal ICA
diagnostic_criteria.ECST_method: [(1 - Nd/Cb) × 100] where Cb = estimated bulb diameter

sources.reference: NASCET Collaborators. N Engl J Med. 1991;325:445-453
Ricotta JJ et al. J Vasc Surg. 2011;54:e1-e31
